item.title: Java vs. C++
item.dc:creator: @Kodiak Kodiak
item.description:
@Kodiak wrote:

Taharok:

Neither is better. I don’t really know why people ask this. It’s per-instance, everytime. Both are completely capable languages. C++ is significantly more powerful, but Java is much faster to work with (generally). Pros and cons to both.

item.title: Java vs. C++
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:27, topic:477374”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=595567.msg4224842#msg4224842 date=1360962698]

plan to further my knowledge in it via college.

Most universities make you learn both C++ and Java

I plan to take specific classes instead of a complete degree. Already looked into University of Phoenix for Java and Javascript.

If you don’t mind my asking, why?
[/quote]
I make less than $400 a month and that pays for bills and gas to work. If I am going to be able to do any classes I can’t afford a full degree[/quote]

You make more than me and pay far less than I do for my education. Everyone has choices.

Regardless, I disagree with nearly everyone on this thread (like usual). Neither C nor C++ are shit. Having thoroughly learned C and having to write a game engine in it, I can say it is extensively difficult to use for large applications. This doesn’t make it shit. It is an extremely good language for low-level operations. That is both its purpose and greatest strength. It is not even close to shit.

C++ and Java. How are they NOT similar? They do have significant differences, yes, but they are both object-oriented. In fact, much of what Java uses was inspired by C (guess where C++ came from) and C++. C++ happens to be a much more powerful language than Java in most situations, but that doesn’t make it superior. C++ is a much harder language to use than Java, so in most examples, I would recommend Java over C++, assuming those are the two choices. The main reason for this is a combination of compatibility and development costs. Developing in Java is very cheap and easy, versus C++ which is much more expensive and difficult. Why overcomplicate things for no reason? Java is better in most situations, and therefore is my recommendation unless you really need the speed and low level functionality, plus the power that C++ offers.

Seriously, this is not even a debate.

Read full topic

item.title: Java vs. C++
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Comparing C++ and Java is like trying to compare Pong and Pac-Man. Its just two totally different languages that don’t even belong in the same sentence. Before you go and say it, yes I know Pong and Pac-Man are in the same games category, but I’m saying they are nothing alike. Every language has its own ups and downs, and you just need to find one that suits what your trying to do best.

I personally prefer Java and plan to further my knowledge in it via college.

Read full topic
